moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6
comment:
Good. Defends the knight at d5 while at the same
time opening development of black's dark squared bishop.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4
comment:
? Definitely
bad. White should try to castle as soon as possible. Also, in the opening,
it's best to develop with attack. 6 Bc4! would be the way to do it (threatens
black's knight at d5). After this, black will get an advantage.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6
comment:
Black's first slip. Black can win a pawn, starting with 7. ... Nxf4 8. Qxf4
Qc7 9. Nf3 f6. Notice white can't take the black pawn on f6 because that would
expose white's queen to attack by the black queen. White's king pawn is what
is called a pin.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6 8. Bb5 Be7 9. Bxc6 dxc6
comment:
When having the option, it is
generally better to capture TOWARD the center of the board. Hence bxc6 is
preferred. In addition, this would give black an excellent post for his queen
bishop on a6. Notice that black's queen bishop doesn't even move this game! If
white does proper defence, this lack of post for thie bishop could've meant a
loss for black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6 8. Bb5 Be7 9. Bxc6 dxc6 10. c4
comment: Very bad. White needs to get pieces out immediately. Nf3 is called for.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6 8. Bb5 Be7 9. Bxc6 dxc6 10. c4 Nxf4 11. Qxf4 Bg5 12. Qf3 Qa5+ 13. Nc3
comment:
White misses a strong defence: Qc3! That
would a) defend the e-pawn b) block the check c) threaten black's queen. Try
to look for moves that do more than one thing at once, if possible.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6 8. Bb5 Be7 9. Bxc6 dxc6 10. c4 Nxf4 11. Qxf4 Bg5 12. Qf3 Qa5+ 13. Nc3 Qxe5+ 14. Nge2 O-O 15. Ne4
comment:
Remember: Using ALL of your chessmen is always more
effective. White could've played the correct O-O, and after Rad1, Rfe1, ALL of
his pieces would be active, while black has a hemmed in light-squared bishop.
White would have real chances to save his game, despite being a pawn minus.
Instead white gives up his b-pawn for free.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6 8. Bb5 Be7 9. Bxc6 dxc6 10. c4 Nxf4 11. Qxf4 Bg5 12. Qf3 Qa5+ 13. Nc3 Qxe5+ 14. Nge2 O-O 15. Ne4 Qxb2 16. O-O Be7
comment:
Good. This rves
the bishop pair. Bishops control more squares on an open board. You could
check this for yourself. Put 2 knights on an empty board in the center, and
they can go to 16 squres. Put 2 bishops in the middle, and they can go to 26
squares!

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6 8. Bb5 Be7 9. Bxc6 dxc6 10. c4 Nxf4 11. Qxf4 Bg5 12. Qf3 Qa5+ 13. Nc3 Qxe5+ 14. Nge2 O-O 15. Ne4 Qxb2 16. O-O Be7 17. g4 f5 18. gxf5 exf5 19. Rab1 Qe5 20. N4g3 g6
comment:
Better is 20. ...
f4, because this would deny white a square for his Knight at f4, in addition
open up the h3-c8 diagonal for black's bishop. With the text, white can play
21. Nf4 Qf6 22. Re1 g5 23. Ng6! Qxg6 24. Rxe7, with chances for white to
survive.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6 8. Bb5 Be7 9. Bxc6 dxc6 10. c4 Nxf4 11. Qxf4 Bg5 12. Qf3 Qa5+ 13. Nc3 Qxe5+ 14. Nge2 O-O 15. Ne4 Qxb2 16. O-O Be7 17. g4 f5 18. gxf5 exf5 19. Rab1 Qe5 20. N4g3 g6 21. Qd3 Rd8 22. f4
comment: ?? Misses black's in-between move. Black should win easily now.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. c3 Nf6 3. e5 Nd5 4. d4 cxd4 5. Qxd4 e6 6. Bf4 Nc6 7. Qd2 h6 8. Bb5 Be7 9. Bxc6 dxc6 10. c4 Nxf4 11. Qxf4 Bg5 12. Qf3 Qa5+ 13. Nc3 Qxe5+ 14. Nge2 O-O 15. Ne4 Qxb2 16. O-O Be7 17. g4 f5 18. gxf5 exf5 19. Rab1 Qe5 20. N4g3 g6 21. Qd3 Rd8 22. f4 Qc5+ 23. Kg2 Rxd3 24. Rbd1 Qxc4 25. Nc1 Qc2+ 26. Nge2 Rxd1 27. Rxd1 Qxd1 28. Kf2 Bc5+ 29. Kf3 Qf1+ 30. Kg3 Qf2+ 31. Kh3 Qf3+ 32. Kh4 Bf2+ 33. Ng3
comment:
So the key thing for
you to remember Peter is to develop ALL of your pieces. You happen to win this
time, but if you could have gotten your rook & bishop active, you win would
have been sure. As it was, white had many chances to get in the game.
